The artist filmed himself sewing a shirt out of movie film. As he sewed, he incorporated the footage he had just shot. When the shirt was finished, he dismantled and re-spliced the shirt. The final movie is the shirt. Yes, you are watching a shirt on multiple levels. Clever and fun.

Full disclosure: I knew the director in college - smartest person I ever met.

As a staunch Obama supporter, I am really disappointed in his address tonight. I give him props for pushing investments in education, infrastructure, etc. that will grow the economy and keep the US competitive. But his ideas on the other side of the ledger, ie getting spending and deficit under control were a complete cop out. Any realistic and honest approach to fiscal discipline has to tackle entitlements--Social Security and Medicare. Establishing the umpteenth commission to study Social Security reform is pathetic when we already know what the options are: raise payroll taxes, raise the retirement age, and cut or means-test benefits. Same on Medicare--we need some combination/subset of raising eligibility age, trimming and/or means-testing benefits, forcing beneficiaries to pay more and raising payroll taxes. Instead, Obama called for nibbling around the edges by more efficient spending, reducing fraud, etc. That's just not going to get us there and I wish he had the guts to say this. Unfortunately I have to give props to Paul Ryan, who in his response, focused almost exclusively on the debt/spending issue, which has the potential to permanently cripple this country in a way that few of the many issues Obama raised can.

Overall, I am hungry for an honest politician to tell me that we all need to sacrifice to right the ship of our country--that means work harder, spend less, pay a bit more in taxes--ALL OF US. I am ready and willing to do this, but Obama's speech left me disappointed again. I hate to say it, but this is forcing me to contemplate supporting the Republicans--if only because they seem more likely to tackle the fiscal sustainability issue more seriously.

John Boehner and his cohorts misread the results of the last election. Yes, they won the House and made inroads in the Senate, but these gains don't necessarily translate into confidence and agreement on GOP policies. First of all, they had no policies; they simply said "no" for two years to all of the Democratic initiatives, and never had policies of their own to offer. The frustrated electorate was really voting against the status quo. Nevertheless, the GOP believes it has a mandate to forge ahead - and now some people are surprised to see what they're getting for those votes.

Obama delineated an overly ambitious agenda for the next two years. It just appeared less arrogant, and more humble. Obviously he is now more experienced in handling politics with the Republican Party. It was a good speech, but unfortunately words don’t act, people do.

The American people will have to see if the next 2 or 6 years provide the President the time he needs for the long term changes America needs.

(Also, the earmarks promise will not be forgotten..., by those who care)

I watched this movie with my 8th grade daughter a part of an assignment from school among a choice of ten other justice or civil rights movies.  The entire movie from cast, scenery and story left a strong impression with me about slavery and life during the decades after the Civil War.  Life did not change for the Black slaves after the war. A story of one person's journey and the people surrounding her is the best way to understand and appreciate this history.  Bravo! to Cicely Tyson--- an actress who deserves the Pulitzer prize for this portrayal -- not just an acting award.  She was absolutely wonderful.   Very, Very well done movie.

For 30 years until the financial crisis, our economy prospered on the basis of people spending money they didn't have, as first, credit cards, then home equity, and finally 401Ks were used to finance daily life.  Since the income gap continues to grow, how can the economy prosper again without recourse to unsustainable consumer debt levels?  In other words, how damaging is our huge income inequality to our economic future?

What a beautiful mash-up of styles and story telling techniques.  There's a sadness at the heart of this film that is devastating. It's also completely fabricated (OK, maybe 10% of it is true).  That doesn't diminish what a great story it is.

Make state taxation more progressive if you want to ensure that wealthy families pay for a larger share of the public university system.

Becker's proposal has the same flaw as the current system. Why should price of a student's education be dependent on his/her parents' income/assets when the parents have no obligation to provide the student with any support?

We have to overcome many years of fiscal abuse by the Republican Party with the capitulation of the Democratic Party that provided improvident tax cuts for the highly rich, two unfunded but major wars, and the current depression. Tax cuts might have been desirable but we did not adjust spending to the cuts we allowed.

The president outlined strategies to confront some of these flaws, but we still need comprehensive tax reform, focus on core matters such as our inability to afford the military policies and forces we now have, and long range but concrete goals.

The $3.4 trillion commercial real estate market is a ticking “time bomb” that may lead to a second wave of losses at large U.S. banks. This looming crisis may lead to significant losses for banks, force shopping center and hotel owners into bankruptcy.
There were 81,315 commercial properties in default, foreclosure or bankruptcy at the end of last year, with hotels and retail among the most problematic.

Wow. A demonstration of how out of touch folks are in the Ivory Towers. First off, as a member of the class being labelled as 'affluent' I would say that I pay a higher tax rate at both the state and federal level than most in the so called middle incomes. That is thanks to our "progressive" tax system. I have no problem with that. These guys are saying, however, that in addition to paying more tax dollars and overall a higher tax rate, that I should be paying more for my kid's tuition.

They also seem to be implying that $200K a year is somehow "affluent". In reality this amounts to the upper middle class- This is the combined salary of a NY State Trooper w/ 10 years on the force married to a high school math teacher w/ 10 years on the job. Hardly "hedge fund" managers, in our 'progressive' tax system, these two barely have significantly more purchasing power than someone grossing half as much.

Further, the earning potential of a college graduate is not what it used to be. A degree in Biology from a good state school, with a top third GPA is going to get you offers in the $40,000/ year range. It's going to take a long time to make a $100,000 investment pay off, much less a 200K one. Also, lost on the authors is the fact the a college caliber individual with some ambition who goes to work instead of college is likely going to be doing as well as that biologist- except that he might be in the black compared to shouldering college debt.

The New York Times gave this a nice affectionate review, saying lots of good things about it and about Claude Lelouch.  I remember being fond of his "A Man and a Woman," even though it really was, as someone said at the time, just the longest Mustang commercial ever made.  This one, in my opinion, is a disaster.  There is no real story, the characters do not live and seem joined by the plot but not by any believable reality, and, believe me, the Times vastly exaggerates the alleged beauty of the locations.  Jeremy Irons is a great actor, capable of fine performances -- this isn't one of them.  New characters who have nothing to do with what little storyline there is (like the boxer and his newly hired handyman) appear out of nowhere and contribute nothing.  The brain tumor/amnesia gimmick is evidently set up to make the ending possible, because its existence does nothing for the rest of the film.  I was very disappointed.
Just dreadful.

My father died last September at the age of 92. Most of the remaining family live in other states and while the exchange of cards and phone calls was a comfort, a webcast to be viewed by family in their homes, surrounded by their loved ones would have been a comfort to those who cannot travel and who called in tears to say how much they loved Dad and would miss him.

David Bartlett (comment #14) obviously does not live in New York, and so is unfamiliar with funeral costs here. Most people must live within their means and here the traditional funeral can cost as much as a mid-size luxury car! I can also remember the days of the funeral ritual - viewing, service at the funeral home, cortege to the church with limousines and funeral cars, church service and then the final trip to the cemetery for the burial. In New York City the only people who can afford that type of sendoff are politicians, real estate developers and gangsters!

While I can imagine a sci-fi novel describing a world where everything takes place online, it is admittedly a worst case scenario.

There is a place for the online funeral. Just as funeral services for certain public figures have been broadcast on TV, providing online access for people who could not otherwise attend would be another helpful way for people to mourn.

I do not find it "grotesque" or silly one bit.  It's lovely that this is offered so so many from far away can participate and feel a part of this type of sad event.  I know someone that used the webcast recently for her husband's funeral, and people from all over, folks that were sick or elderly, could feel a part of the love and also the grief and support the family.  It's a different day and age, and although it should not replace going to the funeral if you can, it is overall a good thing.  Being judgmental of those that have used the online funeral web cast is also, quite rude.
Technology has become a wonderful thing but there are some things technology isn't mean to interfere with. Funerals being one of them.

Triage is a deep and moving study of the horror and unpredictable suddenness of war, this time the Kurdish rebellion against Iraq in 1988. Mark (Colin Farrell) is a war photographer who is severely injured in the fighting and returns home suffering from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. With the help of his wife's grandfather, played flawlessly by 88 year old former horror movie star Christopher Lee, he is able to finally face the shocking events that left the profound shock and guilt that produced his psychological trauma. The cast is simply superb: every role, from the weary, resigned battlefield doctor who must kill his mortally wounded patients to end their suffering, to the pregnant wife of Mark's friend, who is at the center of Mark's trauma, to Mark's own faithful and loving wife. It is a heart-wrenching tale that cannot help but touch and move all but the most cynical among us, arousing our sorrow and compassion for the victims of war, and anger at its brutality and its awful consequences.

Dehumanization at its best. We may as well be robots.  One of the most emotion provoking gatherings reduced to this?  One small step for technology.... 100 giant leaps backwards for humanity. If we keep this up, we'll one day come to understand that Neanderthals & cavemen were more successful in fostering human relationships!
